dataset.title: Application of Talc in Calcium Carbonate-Containing Paper Coating Formulations

creator.organizationName: Department of Environmental Engineering, Dayeh University
Division of Wood Cellulose, Taiwan Forestry Research Institute

abstract.para: Talc has a platy structure with hydrophobic surfaces. There is weak cohesion between the crystal lattices within talc particles, hence it possesses the advantages of a very low frictional coefficient, softness, and low abrasiveness. Talc has been applied to paper coating mainly for low weight coated (LWC) gravure grade and matted art paper for offset printing. Although talc has been widely used in coating formulation in Europe, its application for the coating purpose in Asia still awaits development. The purpose of this study was to use 2 types of talc in place of kaolin clay in calcium carbonate-based coating formulations and investigation of their effects on coating colors and coated paper properties. We aimed to understand the feasibility of such applications and the potential contributions in elevating quality and lowering costs by doing so. The experimental design entailed keeping the ground calcium carbonate (GCC) in a typical art paper color formulation at 70 parts while varying the amounts of no. 1 clay substituted by talc at the 0, 25, 50, 75 and 100% levels. The coating color properties evaluated included solids content, pH, low-shear viscosity, water retention value etc. The coated paper was calendered once in a supercalender and the properties of the coated paper including brightness, opacity, gloss (at 75o), printed gloss (at 60 o), smoothness, coarseness, Leneta, picking resistance, RI wet ink absorption, RI dry picking, RI wet picking, RI drying time etc. were evaluated. The results indicate that technically talc could totally replace no. 1 clay, and the MS-500A grade had better performance. Among the color properties, talc decreased low-shear viscosity but at the cost of sacrificing water retention value to some extent. Among the coated paper properties, talc helped to improve printed gloss, smoothness, coarseness, IGT picking resistance, RI wet ink absorption, dry picking, and wet picking, but tended to decrease gloss and prolong ink drying time. Talc use showed no effects on the brightness and opacity of the coated paper and it is suitable for matte grade coated papers.

section.title: Materials
section.para: Specifications of the main ingredient, base paper, pigments, and chemicals used in the experiments were as follows:

-Coating base paper: bleached hardwood kraft pulp (BHKP) of mixed hardwood (mostly eucalypts), basis weight 91.9 g/m2, manufactured by the Jiutang Mill of the Yuen Fong Yu Paper Co., Kaohsiung, Taiwan. It has a brightness of 83.7 % ISO, and opacity of 88.5%.
-Talc: MS-500A and MS-P500A, both by Jaw Hwa Mining Co., Ltd., Hualien, Taiwan.
-Number 1 clay: α-gloss, J. M. Huber Inc., USA.
-Ground calcium carbonate (GCC): C-90, Imery, Suao, Taiwan.
-Latex: 780 SF, Shin Foong Chemical Industry, Fongshan, Taiwan.

The instruments used for testing the coating color and coated paper included: a Brookfield viscometer (using a no. 4 spindle, at 60 rpm), a Kaltec AA-GWR water retention value meter (1.5 bar, 120 s, and a 5-μm filter), a Hanna pH meter (model 8521), a KRK motor rod type coater, and a KRK supercalender (model : 25F-200E); and optical instruments: a Technidyne gloss meter (model: T480-A), a Technidyne brightness and opacity meter (model: Micro-5S), a Bekk smoothness tester, a Parker Print Surf (PPS) roughness tester; as well as the printing instruments: a RI printability tester, an IGT printability tester, and an IGT Repprotest.

section.title: Methods
section.para: In the experiments, 2 types of talc of differing morphology, MS-500A, and MS-P500A, were separately added to a typical art paper coating formulation entailing 70% GCC and 30% clay to replace varying portions of the clay so as to delineate the influence of talc addition on coating color and coated paper properties. The basic properties of the experimental talc and no. 1 clay are compiled and shown in Table 1. The 2 types of talc, MS-500A and MS-P500A, which SEM diagrams were shown in Figure 1 and particle size distribution in Figure 2, were from different ores with similar mean particle sizes of 1.45 and 1.48 μm, however, 70.2% of MS-500A was smaller than 2.0 μm, whereas only 56.7% of the MS-P500A did. The specific surface area of MS-500A was 8.28 m2 cm-3, greater than the value of 7.40 m2 cm-3 for MS-P500A. In the experimental design, a typical art paper coating formulation having 70 parts of GCC was maintained, while either type of the talc replaced the no. 1 clay with different fractions (0, 25, 50, 75, and 100%) and making up the remaining 30 parts of the pigments. The coating color formulations are shown in Table 2. For each type of talc there were 9 sets of preparations for a total of 17 sets.

The process of coating color preparation proceeded in the order of pigments (talc, clay, and GCC) + distilled water (high-speed mixing) → dispersant (high-speed mixing) → defoamer (high- and low-speed mixing) → etherified starch (low-speed mixing) → latex/lubricant (low speed mixing) → hardener/insolubilizer (low-speed mixing) → NaOH (low-speed mixing) → distilled water (low-speed mixing). The binder (styrene butadiene resin, SBR latex) level was 12 parts of pigments.

The coating color thus prepared was applied to 21.0 x 29.7-cm base sheets using an automatic bar coater (KRK-motor type). The base sheet was preconditioned for 24 h at 20℃ and 65% RH,. The coating amount was adjusted by using bars of different numbers. The coated sheets were immediately placed in an oven maintained at 120℃ for 30 s to dry. Coated paper was supercalendered in a single pass with a KRK 30FC-200E single-nip supercalender having a linear nip pressure of 9.807 x 103 kPa (100 kgf cm-2) and temperature of 55℃. For each coating color, 20 coated test specimens were prepared.

The items of coating color properties tested included solids contents, pH, low-shear viscosity, and water retention value. Properties of the coated sheets tested included brightness, opacity, gloss (at 75o), printed gloss (at 60o), smoothness, roughness (Parker Print Surf test), Leneta (wet brush-out), IGT picking resistance, RI wet ink absorption, RI wet picking, RI dry picking and RI drying time etc.
